abstract.p: Washington Redskins victory over New York Giants discussed (M)

block.p: In looking ahead to the matchup with the Washington Redskins, Giants defenders recalled the embarrassment of last season's 50-21 rout and used it as motivation.

The Giants were able to slow the Redskins' running game; Stephen Davis was far from the unstoppable presence of a year ago. But the Giants' secondary was pierced repeatedly, exposing the holes that had been patched up and safely hidden this season.
In looking ahead to the matchup with the Washington Redskins, Giants defenders recalled the embarrassment of last season's 50-21 rout and used it as motivation.

The Giants were able to slow the Redskins' running game; Stephen Davis was far from the unstoppable presence of a year ago. But the Giants' secondary was pierced repeatedly, exposing the holes that had been patched up and safely hidden this season.

Dave Thomas found himself chasing James Thrash on a 46-yard connection in the second quarter, and then was late helping Jason Sehorn on a 48-yarder to Albert Connell. On the next play, Sam Garnes bit on a pump fake that allowed Irving Fryar to easily move past him for a 23-yard touchdown. Thomas again found himself beaten on a 21-yard score in the third quarter.
The longest pass play of the season for the Redskins in the first three weeks was 26 yards.
The Giants' ''Thunder and Lightning'' backfield of Tiki Barber and Ron Dayne showed some flashes, but nothing like their production over the first three games.

As the Redskins' lead grew larger, the Giants were unable to pound the ball on the ground. In the first half, Barber rushed 9 times for 44 yards, including an 18-yard scamper, while Dayne had just 3 carries for 11 yards. The Giants finished with 93 rushing yards.

Pete Mitchell made a mistake last Monday by assuming he was past his physical problems. Mitchell's luck lasted just over 24 hours. At 1 a.m. Wednesday, he woke up with a sharp pain in his abdomen. He could not return to sleep and after consulting with Ronnie Barnes, the Giants' head trainer, he went to a hospital, where doctors found an ulcer in his intestinal lining.

Considered the only true pass-catching tight end on the Giants' roster, Mitchell missed the first two games of the season with a knee injury he sustained in the first preseason game on Aug. 5. He returned last week against the Bears and was in uniform for tonight's game against Washington.

''I actually made the mistake of telling my wife that this is the best I've felt in a long time,'' Mitchell said. ''My ankle, my knee were feeling better and I was looking forward to a good rest of the year.''
Mitchell returned to limited practice Friday. He received antibiotics and doctors told him he couldn't do any damage to the ulcer.
He has had only three full practices since his knee injury, which required arthroscopic surgery.
